In addition, September 1-4 will be single sessions for students, which includes both in-person and remote schedules. Además, del 1º al 4 de septiembre la jornada escolar terminará al mediodía para los estudiantes, tanto como para los que asisten en-persona como para los que estudian a distancia. El personal docente usará esas tardes para capacitarse en mejorar la educación a distancia para el año 2020-2021. El martes, 8 de septiembre se reanudarán las clases a tiempo completo para los estudiantes.

SENIOR SPOTLIGHT - Summit student athletes
Zach Silberstein - Tennis

From Boys Tennis Coach Bill O'Regan:
Zach enjoyed playing JV tennis as a Hilltopper from the time he was a freshman. It did not matter what was at stake or who he was playing. The simple act of being out there, competing and having fun, was enough. Although Zach never had an opportunity to play as a starter, his role on the team was anchored by a quiet confidence that reminded everyone about the pure enjoyment of just playing the game. Zach always gave everyone his best game and never complained about a lack of playing time, understanding full well that nothing can be taken for granted. The four years Zach spent as a Hilltopper nurtured the beginning of a life-long love of tennis. We expect Zach will lead a fulfilling life where his best game of tennis awaits him on the horizon. #gohilltoppers

post_text: Did you know that Summit High School has a planting club? Student leaders Katya, Caroline, and Jolan have joined their fellow club members at the Summit garden to plant and harvest food weekly for the GRACE Program, which provides food for families in Summit. They have club members head to the garden every other day to water their plot and once a week they work with the coordinator of the Food Pantry Team to harvest the foods that are ready to be donated. They most recently harvested beans, lettuce and onions, but are looking forward to their cucumbers, carrots, tomatoes and peppers being harvested within the following weeks! #gohilltoppers

This opportunity was made possible by the SHS PTO and I greatly thank them for their support." #gohilltoppers

Congratulations to SHS Junior Sara Yoo for being chosen as a 2020 New Jersey Scholar! This year's topic is "Mind and Body: The Future of Being Human". #gohilltoppers

"The mission of the New Jersey Scholars Program is to reach out to able and enthusiastic students who come from a broad cross-section of the state’s population. The program creates an intense, interdisciplinary intellectual experience that will change students’ lives by teaching them to think in a new way — relating disciplines instead of dividing them. Scholars participate in lectures and small-group seminars where they actively engage with the disciplines. They also have extensive reading assignments, and pursue research at world class libraries and museums. They write essays and work closely with a faculty member to produce a 10-15 page interdisciplinary research paper. They are also stretched as they hone their creative talents in art, music, writing, drama and public speaking by contributing to an Arts Festival that is thematically related to the Program topic."

Franklin School was in full swing of their read-aloud of The Wild Robot, when the District had to close. Working collaboratively with School Librarian, Loreli Stochaj, they created a plan to keep things going! Here's a clip of the video Franklin Principal Janice Tierney sent to Franklin families in an effort to connect with students.

Franklin received an SEF grant to engage in a literacy project - "One Book, One School" during the Fall, 2019 grant cycle. They launched this work in January. Every classroom received a copy of the book and had been engaged in read alouds across grade levels with buddy classrooms. The goal was to create a shared literacy experience for every member of the Franklin School community launching with a whole school introductory Read Aloud (January, 2020) of a few chapters and culminating with a family evening Robot Build.

At the end of January, Lawton C. Johnson Summit Middle School hosted Holocaust survivors from The Holocaust Council of Jewish Federation of Greater Metrowest. They addressed the 8th grade students through a program called "Survivors Speak", and shared their experiences. This program was created for The Morris Museum as part of their outreach to schools and it is Summit's seventh year participating.

Along with their language arts teacher, Grace Buonpane, 8th-grade students read The Diary of Anne Frank, and researched the background of that time period.

"As one can imagine, nothing compares to hearing first-hand testimony. The survivors are models of strength and courage and they impact everyone who hears them," said Buonpane.

LCJSMS student volunteers and staff mentors partnered with Grace Healthcare Services to help create memory books for their patients who have Alzheimer's or Dementia, which are debilitating diseases of memory loss.

With the help of volunteers, Grace Healthcare Services creates memory books to use as a communication tool. They categorize items such as food, holidays, sports, cars, flowers/gardens, people, holidays, animals, dolls, clothes, food, homes and accessories.

The volunteers collate these books by finding and cutting out pictures or scenes from magazines, cards, calendars, etc. and then paste them onto sheets and put them into binders. Then, they sit with the patients and review these books to see if any memory is stimulated, and many times it is.

Thank you Hilltoppers for helping others and being a great example of service in the community! #gohilltoppers

LCJSMS students created watercolor paintings highlighting the native fauna and flora of Australia. They displayed the work and hosted a bake sale where all proceeds were donated to W.I.R.E.S., Australia's largest wildlife education and rehabilitation service. Students received donations from families on top of the money they raised during the bake sale, totaling $440!

"Given the recent fires in Australia, we asked ourselves what could we do as a community to help and bring attention to the situation. It was really great to see the middle school students come out and support such a noble cause. After all, it is our responsibility as humans in the animal kingdom to help those unable to help themselves when situations such as the bushfires arise," said Brian Steger, LCJSMS Art Teacher. #gohilltoppers

Summit High School’s Intro to Computer Programming students shared their hard work and detailed programs with the third-grade students at Washington School. These high school students work with a program called Alice, learning the basics of Java programming. They created a ‘typing tutor’ program where different words appear on the screen and the user is prompted to type the letters correctly in order. post_text: Brayton Elementary School had author and illustrator, Daniel Kirk, visit on Thursday, December 12th. He met with 1st, 2nd, and 3rd graders. Ten lucky 3rd graders won the chance to have lunch with him after winning a writing/drawing contest. He is the author and illustrator of over 50 books, including The Library Mouse series and the nonfiction book Rhino in the House. He showed slides from his research trip to a rhino sanctuary in Kenya, sang songs, and showed the students how he draws some of his characters. A great day was had by all! #gohilltoppers

post_text:
PEP Program: Information Session

PEP is a college-access program that offers academic support, social-emotional support, and college tuition assistance to select, motivated students from Summit Public Schools in grades 7 to 12. The program includes subject-based tutoring, study skills and test prep, character development and cultural enrichment, along with on-going post-graduate support. PEP is currently recruiting eligible and motivated 6th graders to join the program for the 2020 - 2021 school year.

To learn more about the PEP Program, attend the PEP Information Session on Tuesday, January 14, 2020 from 6:00pm - 7:00pm at 43 Franklin Place, Summit, NJ 07083 or visit our website at www.pepprogramnj.org.

*Snow date is Thursday, January 23, 2020 at 6:00pm - 7:00pm.
